ContentClassification.TableReference: Richard Price, “Observations on Reversionary Payments, etc., Fourth Edition, Volume II”, (London: Printed for T. Cadell, 1783) p. 36, reprinted by Nelson and Warren, Inc, “Principal Mortality Tables, Old and New”, (St. Louis, MO, 1957) p. 2-3
ContentClassification.TableDescription: Death rates based on population data of Northampton, United Kingdom. Basis: Age at Death. Minimum Age: 0. Maximum Age: 96.
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: The Northampton Table is based on baptism and death records of church parishes (primarily All Saints) in Northampton, U.K. for the periods 1735-1780. The total radix is 11,650. Though later found to be significantly flawed, the Northampton Table has the distinction of being the first to be used by insurance companies and by courts of law in the determination of insurance premiums, annuities, and rights of dower. Methodology: Dr. Price computed rates of mortality and survivorship by comparing deaths with the number of persons living at each age. This construction method assumes the population of the place among whom the deaths occur is stationary. Such an assumption is consistent with mortality table construction practices of Europe in the 18th and 19th centuries. To procure data for a life table, the preferred method was to select a province in which the population was stationary; not much affected by either immigration or emigration, and free from pestilence or other depopulating calamities. Reliance on birth and death records maintained by churches is also consistent with table construction practices of the time as populations seldom left their place of birth during said time in history. Dr. Price noted at publication that the number of deaths exceeded the number of baptisms observed and arbitrarily attributed the additional deaths to immigration at age 20. In addition to this erroneous immigration assumption, Dr. Price overlooked that many children born were not baptized and he neglected to account for population statistics. Had census data but captured, a rising birth rate during the period of study would have been noted. Dr. Price furthermore made adjustments to the number of deaths. He showed exactly 75 deaths at every age from 21 to 39, 82 deaths each year from age 51 to 61, and 80 deaths front 64 to 75. Collectively, these flaws meant mortality of the Northampton Table was over-stated. Nevertheless, the Northampton Table was in use for an extended period of time. Data Transcription Errors Detected: 09/13/2007. Data Corrected and Certified: 09/26/2012.

MetaData.TableDescription: Death rates based on population data of Northampton, United Kingdom. Basis: Age at Death. Minimum Age: 0. Maximum Age: 96.
